title: Mississippi Legislature Passes Bill to Change State Flag
summary: Bill now heads to Republican Gov. Tate Reeves, who has pledged to sign it. The legislature in Mississippi, the last state with the Confederate battle emblem on its flag, voted by a wide margin Sunday to change the state's flag after 126 years.

title: Virus Surges in Parts of U.S. as Global Cases Top 10 Million
summary: U.S. records more than 42,000 new infections; Florida, Texas, California and Arizona account for much of the rise. Coronavirus cases world-wide passed 10 million, with more than 500,000 deaths, as parts of the U.S. took steps to reverse their reopenings in response to surging case numbers, especially among young people.

title: Defense Secretary to Give Trump Options on U.S. Presence in Germany
summary: Some fear a troop withdrawal from Germany would embolden U.S. adversaries, including Russia. Defense Secretary Mark Esper will on Monday present to the White House options to reduce the U.S. military presence in Germany by nearly 10,000 troops in what would be a dramatic reshaping of the U.S. presence in Europe.

title: Fracking Trailblazer Chesapeake Energy Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Oklahoma City-based company was once the second-largest U.S. gas producer. Chesapeake Energy Corp. filed for bankruptcy protection Sunday as an oil- and gas-price rout stoked by the coronavirus pandemic proved to be the final blow for a shale-drilling pioneer long hamstrung by debt.

title: Covid Comparisons, Europe and U.S.
summary: The America-is-a-failure reporting has a heavy dose of partisanship.. Scientists are studying why the coronavirus hasn't had more of a resurgence in Europe after countries lifted their lockdowns while some U.S. states battle explosive outbreaks. But the epidemiologists in the media already know why: GOP Governors and President Trump ignored public-health guidelines and reopened too fast and too soon.

title: Ramping Up the Speech Intimidation
summary: Democrats harass a company for working with nonprofits.. It's election season, so it's time for Democrats in Congress to try to shut down donations to conservative nonprofits.

title: All Hail the Lobster King
summary: Step one: Boil Maine's lobster industry. Step two: Bail it out.. We hope Peter Navarro has received his updated business cards. At a meeting in Maine this month with commercial fishermen, President Trumpwas told how his trade war has devastated the state's lobster industry. Mr. Trump said he'd get his trade adviser working on it posthaste: "Peter Navarro is going to be the Lobster King now, OK?"

title: FAA to Start Boeing 737 MAX Test Flights
summary: Certification flights mark milestone for returning fleet to commercial service. U.S. air-safety regulators are set to begin key flight tests of Boeing Co.'s 737 MAX as early as Monday, amid growing expectations by industry and government officials that the planes are likely to return to service around the end of the year.

title: FDIC Considers Scrapping Quarterly Bank Reports
summary: Agency to kick off competition to develop new reporting prototype that provides timely data on bank risks. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is moving to boost the way it monitors for risks at thousands of U.S. banks, potentially scrapping quarterly reports that have been a fixture of oversight for more than 150 years yet often contain stale data.

title: Poland's President Wins First Round of Election
summary: Duda gets 42% of the votes, according to exit polls, as turnout breaks quarter-century-old records. WARSAW-Poland's President Andrzej Duda won the first round of an election on Sunday, but without the simple majority he needed to avoid a runoff, as turnout broke quarter-century-old records in the European Union's first national election since the coronavirus pandemic swept the continent.

title: Bars Get Snagged in Covid-19 Reopening Reversals
summary: Owners struggle to stay open as bars become a source of coronavirus flare-ups.

title: Automakers, Technology Firms Are Largest Components of Fed's Corporate-Bond Purchases
summary: The central bank disclosed the names of 794 companies whose bonds it began purchasing this month. Apple Inc., Verizon Corp. and the U.S. divisions of several foreign auto makers are among the largest direct beneficiaries of Federal Reserve efforts to support the corporate-debt market, according to disclosures Sunday.

title: Outdoor Dining Pushes New York City Restaurants to Rethink Menus
summary: Chefs aim for 'fun summer vibe' with lighter fare, less fuss and on-street cooking. When outdoor restaurant-dining started as part of New York's recent phase-two reopening, Nick Pfannerstill, chef at Mother's Ruin, a cocktail bar and dining spot in Manhattan's Nolita neighborhood, realized he had more to worry about than social distancing and table placement.

title: Leahy's Yankee Imperialism
summary: The senator tries to block a nominee to the Inter-American Development Bank.. The days of arrogant American politicians telling Latin American countries what's good for them were supposed to be over. But last week Vermont's Sen. Patrick Leahy reminded the world that old habits die hard.

title: How to Slay a Tech Giant (Apple)
summary: Dominant firms try to do everything, but a network of smaller peers can do it better.. When Apple announced last week that it will soon replace Intel processors with its own, I had a flashback to 1993. Morgan Stanley 's technology investment banker Frank Quattrone called me in New York: "John Sculley"-CEO of Apple-"wants to meet with you Friday," he said. It was Thursday morning. "About what?" I asked. "I don't know, do your virtual thing." I booked the 9 p.m. to San Francisco and the redeye home.

title: 'The Great Indoors' Review: Better Living by Design
summary: 'Intelligent environments' that layer technology into architecture can improve the function of organizations and the well-being of individuals.. In August 2015, scientists planning for a future Mars mission locked a mock crew of six in an isolated, self-contained habitat in Hawaii for a year and monitored what happened under the quarantine-like conditions. It wasn't pretty. Tensions flared, and rifts formed. What the crew members craved from their living environment was privacy, a place where the sights, sounds and scents of others weren't constantly intruding on them.

title: Powell Has Become the Fed's Dr. Feelgood
summary: Overprescription of monetary medicine has the economy addled, addicted and searching for a fix.. If Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell were selling a prescription drug instead of a monetary policy, the Food and Drug Administration would likely want a word with him. "What we're thinking about now is providing the accommodation that this economy needs for as long as it needs it. That's all we're thinking about," the central banker told the Senate Banking Committee on June 16.

title: Local Elections Deliver Blow to France's Macron
summary: Republic on the Move party suffers a string of losses in municipal elections across France. PARIS-President Emmanuel Macron's party suffered a string of losses in municipal elections across France on Sunday, raising doubts about the long-term survival of a political movement built around the French leader.

title: Reinvent Health Care to Beat Covid-19
summary: Important surgeries can continue, but doctors need to be paid more for managing outbreaks.. Many states face Covid epidemics that are proving hard to quell. America will have to deal with Covid as a significant threat for perhaps six more months, until a vaccine is ready. It's a short period in our long history. But so far we haven't been able to muster the collective will to control the spread.

title: The Disparate Racial Impact of Requiring a College Degree
summary: Among U.S. workers over 25, only 26% of blacks, and 40% of whites, have a bachelor's or higher.. In response to the senseless and brutal killing of George Floyd, major brands are flooding social media with statements in support of the black community. Bank of America followed up with a $1 billion philanthropic commitment. As of June 18, Fortune 100 companies had pledged more than $2 billion to demonstrate that they are listening and responding.

title: Notable & Quotable: Minneapolis
summary: The city is 'spending $4,500 a day for private security for three council members who . . . have been outspoken proponents of defunding the Minneapolis Police Department.'. Tom Lyden reporting for KMSP-TV in Minneapolis, June 27:

title: Strategy Behind Blockbuster Grubhub Deal: Don't Deliver
summary: Bid by Dutch giant Just Eat Takeaway would join two companies that have avoided building their own delivery fleets. In its $7 billion deal to buy Grubhub Inc., a Dutch food-delivery giant is betting on a strategy it has relied on for years in Europe: Let restaurants deliver their own food.

title: Getting Rid of All Those Suspect Roosevelts
summary: The offended parties should logically move on to expunging Theodore Roosevelt's oppressive cousin Franklin Roosevelt.. Regarding your editorial "Teddy Gets Canceled" (June 23): The offended parties should logically move on to expunging Theodore Roosevelt's oppressive cousin Franklin Roosevelt. FDR was a president who marched tens of thousands of American citizens of Japanese descent into concentration camps. Historians politely labeled them "internment camps" but the Japanese survivors and the courts have restored the rightful label, and survivors have been paid $1.6 billion in reparations.

title: Cities Could Deter Urban Exodus but Won't
summary: Running the numbers, I found that what my wife and I would pay in New York City and state income taxes alone would be more than our entire current rent for our high-rise apartment in Dallas.. It comes as no surprise that so many of those who are able are fleeing some of America's largest cities ("The Coming Urban Exodus" by Daniel Henninger, Wonder Land, June 18). Early this year, I switched jobs. When negotiating, I was asked which office I wanted to be based out of as most of my team is in the New York City metro area. Running the numbers, I found that what my wife and I would pay in city and state income taxes alone would be more than our entire current rent for our high-rise apartment in Dallas. Texas is a state with no income tax. Neither of us have hit 30 yet, so I can't even imagine what it's like for those further into their careers or who have children. We choose not to allow our hard-earned money to prop up decades of reckless mismanagement by leadership which has openly pushed out businesses, kicked the can down the road on looming pension liabilities and prohibited development to the point where it's a trope. Leaders in these big-government cities should focus on reducing taxes and regulations to ensure their 21st century is as great as the 20th was, but I fear it will just be used as another excuse to raise taxes.

title: Personal Agency Is Required For Real Human Dignity
summary: Ian Rowe's comments are a modern take on what Frederick Douglass also advised in his 1859 "Self-Made Men" speech.. Regarding Ian Rowe's "The Power of Personal Agency" (op-ed, June 22): I applaud Mr. Rowe for pointing out the importance of everyone, regardless of their race or socioeconomic background, to take personal responsibility for their own lives and futures. Mr. Rowe's comments are a modern take on what Frederick Douglass also advised in his 1859 "Self-Made Men" speech: "The lesson taught at this point by human experience is simply this, that the man who will get up will be helped up; and the man who will not get up will be allowed to stay down. This rule may appear somewhat harsh, but in its general application and operation it is wise, just and beneficent. I know of no other rule which can be substituted for it without bringing social chaos. Personal independence is a virtue and it is the soul out of which comes the sturdiest manhood. But there can be no independence without a large share of self-dependence, and this virtue cannot be bestowed. It must be developed from within."

title: Economy Week Ahead: Factories, Inflation, Employment
summary: Economists expect factory activity to grow but at slower pace than in April; eurozone consumer inflation for June is projected to remain tepid. The U.S. employment report highlights the week's data, which is expected to show more economic growth as the world tentatively climbs out of a coronavirus-induced recession.

title: Retirement Security and Passively Managed Funds
summary: A fiduciary must avoid investments that underperform. Why then are plans permitted to invest in actively managed funds that consistently underperform passively managed funds?. In "Retirees' Security Trumps Other Social Goals" (op-ed, June 24), Labor Secretary Eugene Scalia states: "A fiduciary's duty is to retirees alone . . . retirement security for American workers." Thus, the fiduciary must avoid investments that underperform. Why then are plans permitted to invest in actively managed funds that consistently underperform passively managed funds?

title: Even the Bible Is Full of Flawed Characters
summary: The destruction of monuments only impoverishes our sense of history.. Years ago I was dedicating a new parish to St. Peter. A woman wrote to protest: "Why would you name a Church after such a coward, a sinner who denied even knowing the Lord when Jesus needed him most, at the hour of His arrest and crucifixion?"

title: How Do Doctors Treating Coronavirus Relax? By Playing the Game 'Pandemic'
summary: Resume Subscription. As associate medical director of the Duke Infection Control Outreach Network in North Carolina, Sonali Advani assists more than 50 hospitals in the Southeast on dealing with the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Officials Press Trump to Wear Mask in Coronavirus Fight
summary: Speaker Pelosi says wearing a face mask in public should be required of all Americans. President Trump is coming under growing pressure from Republicans and Democrats to set an example for the country by wearing a face mask as the number of U.S. coronavirus cases hits new highs.

title: Texas Tried Reopening Offices Early. It Was Hard Even Before the Coronavirus Surge.
summary: Resume Subscription. Texas got back to work faster than most states. It now serves as a warning to the nation: reopening offices and other businesses may be messier and more prone to disruption than many imagined.

title: Coronavirus Erases Guidance From 40% of S&P 500
summary: Companies that have pulled their outlook have collectively underperformed the broader market; 'there are still many unknown factors'. More than 40% of the companies in the S&P 500 have pulled their guidance, as the coronavirus pandemic has doused U.S. corporations in uncertainty, and their shares together have fallen more than the broader index.

title: New York's Top Black Policeman Addresses 'Passionate Outrage'
summary: NYPD Deputy Commissioner Benjamin Tucker says more overhauls in training and disciplining officers will help chart a course forward for the force. When Benjamin Tucker joined the New York Police Department in 1969, he was one of only a few black officers.

title: Trump Removes Tweet With 'White Power' Reference
summary: Republican Sen. Tim Scott had called the Twitter post 'indefensible' after the president shared it. President Trump removed a tweet Sunday in which he shared a video showing one of his supporters yelling "white power" at an opponent at a political rally in Florida.

title: Casinos Consider Cashless Gambling to Fight Coronavirus
summary: Hoards of cash are part of Las Vegas lore, but handling currency sparks fears of infection. The U.S. casino industry remains a bastion of cash in an increasingly cashless world, where high-security vaults storing millions of dollars have inspired heist movies and the living-large vibe of Las Vegas is ferried in bags bulging with currency.

title: Fratricidal Clash in West Africa Pits al Qaeda Against Islamic State
summary: Resume Subscription. Islamic State fighters, after a year killing soldiers and villagers along the desert frontier between Mali and Burkina Faso, recently detonated a truck bomb aimed at a new target: al Qaeda.

title: Coronavirus Crisis Strains Russia's Soviet-Era Regional Health System
summary: Doctors, equipment and basic supplies run short as cases climb; some facilities lack running water. KARABANOVO, Russia-In mid-April, when the hospital in this hardscrabble rural town saw its first confirmed coronavirus infections, the district's chief doctor ordered 16 nurses and doctors to quarantine at the facility, together with 40 patients, many suspected of having the virus.

title: Companies Try New Tactic to Tap Climate-Sensitive Investors
summary: Transition bonds are emerging as a new asset class in the debt market, creating a link between fossil-fuel companies and ESG investing. When Cadent Gas Ltd. needed to replace parts of its pipeline network across England this year, it raised €500 million selling a new type of debt, known as transition bonds.

title: Fed Looks Down Under for Rate Strategy
summary: Central bank eyes Australia's experience with so-called yield caps to keep interest rates low amid the downturn. SYDNEY-With the Fed considering a new monetary policy tool to help hold interest rates low amid the severe downturn, clues to the tactic's effectiveness can be found in one advanced economy far away.

title: Big-Tech Investors Need to Start Watching Brussels More Closely
summary: Proposals for new powers could arm enforcers to push through more fundamental changes to how the likes of Apple and Google operate in Europe. For all the noise they have generated, European Union efforts to regulate U.S. tech giants haven't exactly kept investors awake at night. But that might be starting to change.

title: Russell Golden Leaves FASB With Streamlined Standards, Lingering Rule Questions
summary: The departing chairman helped implement new accounting rules on leases and revenue recognition, but some investors say details are lacking. The Financial Accounting Standards Board's Russell Golden shepherded a handful of sweeping rule changes during his tenure as chairman, but for some investors, he didn't go far enough.

title: Private Equity's Trillion-Dollar Piggy Bank Holds Little for Struggling Companies
summary: Barriers stand between buyout firms' cash pile and the businesses in need that they own. The mountain of cash held by private-equity firms is turning out to be a mirage for companies they own that are struggling due to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: U.S. Presses Europe to Uproot Chinese Security-Screening Company
summary: American agencies lobby allies against Nuctech, saying maker of cargo, baggage-scanning systems at Western gateways poses threat to security, businesses. The U.S. is targeting China's largest maker of security-screening equipment, saying its expanding presence in Europe is a threat to Western security and businesses, according to documents and people familiar with the matter.

title: How App Makers Break Their Apps to Avoid Paying Apple
summary: Apple's App Store rules and commissions are why some developers won't let you sign up for services or buy digital media in their apps-and even overcharge you when they do.. You've avoided Netflix for years, especially since you're already paying through the nose for cable. But everybody kept talking-and talking and talking-about "Tiger King." One night, after crawling into bed, you caved and downloaded the app on your iPhone.

title: Cable News Networks to Team Up on Convention Coverage Amid Pandemic
summary: CNN, MSNBC, Fox News in talks to coordinate pool coverage to reduce number of journalists in potentially infectious areas. Two years ago, CNN staffers descended on Charlotte, N.C., to start planning coverage of the 2020 Republican convention, scouting hotels and broadcast sites and even picking out a local watering hole where the network would host political power players.

title: Travel Bans Take Shine Off Banks' Premium Rewards Cards
summary: Banks are offering extra points on groceries, lowering annual fees to keep customers happy; 'These aren't minor changes'. For more than 20 years, Laura Chapman routinely charged thousands of dollars a month on her American Express Co. Platinum card.

title: Shooting at California Distribution Center Leaves One Dead
summary: The 31-year-old shooter, who was killed by police, had a history with the Walmart distribution center. RED BLUFF, Calif-A man drove into a Northern California distribution center and started shooting at people, killing an employee and wounding four others before he was killed by police, authorities said.

title: A Row Over Trees Could Spark the Next War Between Israel and Lebanon
summary: The neighbors have come to blows over vegetation before, and the dispute is deadly serious. RAMYAH, Lebanon-At the heart of tensions that threaten to trigger a new war between Israel and Lebanon are lines of trees planted along their blurred border.

title: Pandemic Led to Surge in Alzheimer's Deaths
summary: As Covid-19 raced through long-term care facilities, it amplified mortality risks for those with Alzheimer's and other forms of dementia. At least 15,000 more Americans have died in recent months from Alzheimer's disease and dementia than otherwise would have, health officials believe, pointing to how the coronavirus pandemic has exacted a higher fatality toll than official numbers have shown.

title: The Word of God in the Age of Weed
summary: As more believers begin to tolerate legalization, current and former religious leaders find themselves in the middle of a debate over health, race and law enforcement. Sue Taylor never would have let one of her students slide 20 years ago if she had caught one with marijuana.

title: Cycling, Rollerblading and Pickleball Keep This 88-Year-Old Fit
summary: Former research scientist works out three times a day while training for the National Senior Games. Leurene Hildenbrand credits the coronavirus pandemic for her improved pickleball stamina. "If we rally longer, we touch the ball less," she says. At 88, Ms. Hildenbrand uses pickleball-a cross between tennis and ping pong-to keep fit and stay social.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: New York reopens, protesters march in Washington, couples reunite in Spain, and more. Michal Levi and two of her children look toward the nearby Palestinian city of Rawabi from Ateret, their West Bank settlement. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is now considering how far he wants to go toward fulfilling his campaign pledge to annex parts of the occupied West Bank. Read more

title: American Companies Find Willing Buyers of Debt Abroad
summary: Asian and European firms have rushed to buy U.S. corporate bonds, attracted by higher yields and falling costs for hedging currency risk. Overseas investors are flocking to buy U.S. corporate bonds, aiding a recovery in credit markets that were thrown into disarray by the pandemic.

title: Public Transit Use Is Tied to Higher Covid-19 Death Rates
summary: African-Americans' greater use of public transportation could partly explain their higher rate of Covid-19 deaths, two studies suggest. African-Americans may be dying at higher rates than white people from Covid-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus, in part because of black people's heavier reliance on public transportation for commuting, two new studies by economists suggest.

title: What to Do When Your First Job Isn't a Good Fit
summary: The economic downturn means many college graduates aren't landing their dream jobs right away; here's how to turn a less-than-perfect position into a career stepping-stone. Libby Otto had a plan. Graduate from Bryn Mawr College . Move to Washington.

title: Surge in Covid-19 Cases Tests Austin's Reopening
summary: The Texas capital offers a look at the challenges and tensions involved in trying to restart an economy. For months, Nelly Garcia has operated her family's custom bakery out of her third-floor apartment, working 13-hour days to keep up with an increase in demand.

title: New York Senate GOP Leader Vows Tougher Stance Against Democrats
summary: Robert Ortt of Niagara County says state residents deserve balance. Robert Ortt, the new leader of the Senate Republican conference, says he plans to be an aggressive presence at a state Capitol where Democrats now control all the levers of power.

title: Mississippi Moves One Step Closer to Replacing State Flag
summary: State is last one to feature Confederate emblem on its flag; governor says he will sign a bill. The legislature in Mississippi, the last state with the Confederate battle emblem on its flag, has taken a major step to change the state's flag.
